title: LegoSLM: Connecting LLM with Speech Encoder using CTC Posteriors
author: Rao Ma (University of Cambridge), Tongzhou Chen (Google Deepmind), Kartik Audhkhasi (Google Deepmind), Bhuvana Ramabhadran (Google Deepmind), ...
relevance_why: The integration of speech encoders with large language models (LLMs) using Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) posteriors can inspire novel methods in audio processing and enhance models for speech restoration and generation tasks.
background: The paper investigates combining a speech encoder and a large language model to improve performance in automatic speech recognition and speech translation tasks.
contribution: LegoSLM introduces a novel method to bridge pre-trained speech encoders and large language models using CTC posteriors, achieving significant performance improvements across multiple tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods either connect speech and text representations directly or rely on ASR hypotheses for language model refinement, risking information loss.
technical_comparison.novelty: LegoSLM maintains high fidelity of audio information by using CTC posteriors, allowing greater flexibility in model use while minimizing privacy concerns.

key_innovation: This method reconstructs speech embeddings from CTC posteriors, promoting a modular architecture where different speech encoders can be integrated without retraining the large language model.
real_world_impact: This framework could significantly improve speech recognition and translation applications, enhancing accessibility and user interaction with automated systems across various domains.
limitations: The authors foresee limitations in terms of dependency on the speech encoder's vocabulary aligning with the LLM's, although their method shows robustness in mismatched cases.

new_terms.Connectionist Temporal Classification (C: **Connectionist Temporal Classification** is a neural network architecture used for sequence-to-sequence tasks that does not require pre-defined alignment between input and output sequences.
new_terms.ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition): **Automatic Speech Recognition** refers to the technology that enables a computer to identify and process human speech into a written format.
